xwikidoc.title: IRC Archive for channel #phenotips on 28 May 2013
xwikidoc.content: <kushalkhandelwal> has joined #phenotips 00:09 <kushalkhandelwal> is now known as <Guest22512> 00:11 <kushalk124> has joined #phenotips 01:30 <kushalk124> has quit 01:31 <Guest22512> has quit 01:44 <Guest22512> has joined #phenotips 02:14 <Guest22512> has quit 02:31 <Guest22512> has joined #phenotips 04:38 <ravigarg27> has quit 04:48 <Guest22512> is now known as <kushalkhandelwal> 07:00 <BogdanVancea1_> has quit 07:26 <kushalkhandelwal> has quit 08:28 <ravigarg27> has joined #phenotips 08:30 <sdumitriu> Hey Ravi 08:42 <ravigarg27> hii sdumutriu1 08:43 <sdumitriu> What are you working on? 08:44 <ravigarg27> the problem you gave yesterday 08:44 <ravigarg27> if the words are inversed 08:49 <sdumitriu> So, what's your idea? 08:50 <ravigarg27> is needleman wunsch the way to go about? 08:51 <ravigarg27> I also thought of splitting words and calculating similarity score for each words with others 08:52 <ravigarg27> and then summing up the maximum of similarity score of each word 09:01 <ravigarg27> but this will be computationally intensive 09:02 <ravigarg27> so am seeing the working of needleman algorithm 09:03 <sdumitriu> No, NW is not the right approach 09:03 <sdumitriu> There are adaptations of SW that have different types of gaps 09:04 <sdumitriu> I can't find it now, but there's a sequence alignment that differentiates between codon skips and frameshifts 09:05 <sdumitriu> I'm not sure there is one with word swaps (or codon swaps, as it would be called for DNA), but it's quite simple to write it 09:09 <ravigarg27> ohh okay 10:49 <ravigarg27> has quit 11:12 <sdumitriu1> has joined #phenotips 12:40 <ravigarg27> has joined #phenotips 13:46 <ravigarg27> has quit 15:38 <BogdanVancea> has quit 16:02 <sdumitriu1> has quit 23:16 <sdumitriu> has quit 23:18 <sdumitriu> has joined #phenotips
